We love you guys!

snippet.textDisplay: This is a really good question to weed out racists. Non-racists will simply answer no, or state the fact that they technically are since everyone is to some degree racist. Racists on the other hand will jump on the defence, avoid/attack the question, antagonise the asker. Non-racists are not afraid that someone's definition of racist may include them.

snippet.textDisplay: Racism is a SYSTEM backed by institutionalized power and enforcement (by police). Black people have never had that privilege or power, that's why blacks and other POC can't really be racist, we get no benefits from it! Now POC can be very prejudice as a result from racism but "reverse racism" doesn't exist...period! The words "racism" and "prejudice" are NOT interchangeable, even though people confused them all the time. Why is that so hard to get!

snippet.textDisplay: Everyone here in the comment section is confusing racism as it is popularly defined: discrimination against a race and as it actually should be defined: the institutional oppression of one race that benefits another.  Because the only racist institutions left are made by white people towards a great variety of other races and ethnic groups, it is impossible for blacks to be racist as in contributing to institutional oppression, however they can most definitely be prejudiced as that is discrimination on an individual level.

snippet.textDisplay: There are 2 thoughts that initially go through someone's head when they see someone out of their norm (black, asian, trans, gay, etc) . Their initial response is their innate human response, their second response is the conscientious decision to verbalize it. That 2nd thought is what  defines if you are a racist, do you actively choose to say it?

snippet.textDisplay: Was very surprised by these answers. I think all races are capable of racism, but I did appreciate the guys point of view of how he feels his race has not experienced an institutional level to suppress another race. I don’t think all white people are racist, I believe we all are raised in a world fueled by hate and race unfortunately is an underlining factor people are judged on but that does not mean all people believe this is right. Think all people are prejudice and or judgmental at some degree and I would like to believe almost people actively try to correct the faults in themselves to contribute to a better society. Thank you for this video 💕

snippet.textDisplay: I don't understand why so many people in this comment section believe blacks cannot be racist to whites. They say it's based on "oppression", but that isn't really the definition of racism, it's just believing your race is superior to another and having a prejudice towards them. And even IF it was based on oppression what about white people and white kids who are not in any positions of power? I sure as hell am not, I was raised in a lower-middle-class household and went to a primarily Mexican school and I've been called too much racist shit to keep track of. I don't understand, how am I personally any different than a black kid the same age as me? Wheres my privilege? People are allowed to shit on me and be racist towards me because I was born white?
snippet.textOriginal: I don't understand why so many people in this comment section believe blacks cannot be racist to whites. snippet.textDisplay:
4:30 + 4:43 + 4:46 Pretty much the best combination of answers. It's the same with any other flaws. Take laziness for example. You don't eliminate laziness for good, you work on it every day, you make sure that you don't fall back on it, and you make sure to impart your environment the idea of discipline as a good value. That's a continuous process, it will never go away, you don't just wake up and laziness disappears in the world, it needs constant readdressing and motivation to keep. It's the same with racism, it will never be gone, we'll always have to look at it through different perspectives and deal with new forms of it, coming from everyone and targeting everyone. That's just how it is. It's as much a part of your life as any other responsibility that you have.


So all the people with their "it will go away if we don't talk about it" or "when is it finally enough, we're not racist anymore", yeah your arguments are pretty bad, you're the guys who lose weight and then think all is good forever and that you don't have to take care of your diet anymore and all will be fine. That's not how it works though. That's just running away from your responsibility.

The difference is that with laziness, at least you mostly only harm yourself and not others.
snippet.textOriginal:
4:30 + 4:43 + 4:46 Pretty much the best combination of answers. It's the same with any other flaws. Take laziness for example. You don't eliminate laziness for good, you work on it every day, you make sure that you don't fall back on it, and you make sure to impart your environment the idea of discipline as a good value. That's a continuous process, it will never go away, you don't just wake up and laziness disappears in the world, it needs constant readdressing and motivation to keep. It's the same with racism, it will never be gone, we'll always have to look at it through different perspectives and deal with new forms of it, coming from everyone and targeting everyone. That's just how it is. It's as much a part of your life as any other responsibility that you have.


So all the people with their "it will go away if we don't talk about it" or "when is it finally enough, we're not racist anymore", yeah your arguments are pretty bad, you're the guys who lose weight and then think all is good forever and that you don't have to take care of your diet anymore and all will be fine. That's not how it works though. That's just running away from your responsibility.

The difference is that with laziness, at least you mostly only harm yourself and not others.

snippet.textDisplay: If you redefine the term "racism" so that it no longer means the same thing as the phrase racial prejudice, then the word becomes nothing more than the expression of a social justice warrior religious belief, unsupported by evidence, that certain races are morally superior to others because of some kind of imaginary, collective victimhood.   The word becomes an authorization to hate and to not take responsibility for one's own life.  Universities, through their twisting of language in attempting to redefine racism, have managed to destroy virtually everything accomplished by the Civil Rights Movement.  Actual racial prejudice is re-established as something valid and justifiable, when directed against lighter skinned people by darker skinned people.
snippet.textOriginal: If you redefine the term "racism" so that it no longer means the same thing as the phrase racial prejudice, then the word becomes nothing more than the expression of a social justice warrior religious belief, unsupported by evidence, that certain races are morally superior to others because of some kind of imaginary, collective victimhood.   The word becomes an authorization to hate and to not take responsibility for one's own life.  Universities, through their twisting of language in attempting to redefine racism, have managed to destroy virtually everything accomplished by the Civil Rights Movement.  Actual racial prejudice is re-established as something valid and justifiable, when directed against lighter skinned people by darker skinned people.

snippet.textDisplay: Too many people don't know what the word "racist" means.  If you're a racist, you think one race is inferior to another race BASED ON NOTHING BUT THEIR ACTUAL RACE.  For example, saying Asians are bad drivers is not racist.  You're making an observation based on personal experience. It might be an insensative, unfair stereotype, but it's not RACIST.
snippet.textOriginal: Too many people don't know what the word "racist" means.  If you're a racist, you think one race is inferior to another race BASED ON NOTHING BUT THEIR ACTUAL RACE.  For example, saying Asians are bad drivers is not racist.  You're making an observation based on personal experience. It might be an insensative, unfair stereotype, but it's not RACIST.

snippet.textDisplay: It’s kind of hard to say that but it is true that I’m most likely to cross the street if it’s a black man than a white man, although the clothes influence a lot too. I live in Brazil, most specifically Salvador, where 75% of the poor are black (which means that probably they live in the favelas, which can be a very violent place). So, I’m afraid of people that I judge poor when im walking in the street because I don’t know their character, I don’t know if they are a bad or a good person, and I know also that there are bad rich people, but they are not gonna assault me to get money, because they don’t need to. It happens that since the majority of poor people here are black it looks that I’m crossing the street only because they are black, that’s not the truth. It’s sad and I’m ashamed of it, but if you lived here you would know that you can’t joke around here, if one day you decide not to get judgmental and trust the people that you don’t know, your prejudice is most likely to become real and you’ll get assaulted.

snippet.textDisplay: The reason people say "black people can't be racist" is because they define racism as the systematic and institutionalized concept, vs discrimination or prejudice, like thinking white people can't cook or mocking Mandarin. This definition of racism stems from a top down concept covering the ability to get jobs, housing, likelihood to be jailed, etc. Basically, only the racial majority, or ones in power, have the ability to systematically and consistently suppress other racial groups. This isn't to say black people can't be ignorant, prejudice, or even yes racist based on personal definition, I just wanted to shed some light on the definition of racism in question here.
snippet.textOriginal: The reason people say "black people can't be racist" is because they define racism as the systematic and institutionalized concept, vs discrimination or prejudice, like thinking white people can't cook or mocking Mandarin. This definition of racism stems from a top down concept covering the ability to get jobs, housing, likelihood to be jailed, etc. Basically, only the racial majority, or ones in power, have the ability to systematically and consistently suppress other racial groups. This isn't to say black people can't be ignorant, prejudice, or even yes racist based on personal definition, I just wanted to shed some light on the definition of racism in question here.

snippet.textDisplay:
So much indoctrination here for incessant semantics. 10 yrs ago racism was for the most part an archaic belief of ones superiority almost gone extinct. With regard to real racism and bigotry exisisting now, today in America? The little percentage of the gross population across the entire spectrum of skin tone, of what remains of racist believing / behaving people is because....
Racism will always exist by the evidence of the racist people behaving and believing racistly.

What is lost in all of the semantics I see in this thread is one simple prudent thing to the thriving potential of our Humanity....

Does anybody remember the Golden Rule? Everybody has the ability to treat others kindly. If only we treated each other so kindly as we would like to all be treated ourselves. I think toddlers get this without any difficulty it amazes me how adults so often do not.
